source.heading: A. D.
source.body: Altenglische Dichtungen der MS, Härl. 2253, herausgegeben von K. Boddeker, Berlin, 1878.

source.heading: A. P.
source.body: v. Allit. Pms.

source.heading: A. R.
source.body: The Ancren Riwle, edited for the Camden Society (No. lvii.) by J. Morton, 1853. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Abus.
source.body: Codex Junii 23, fol. 60, in the Bodleian Library. See Wanley's Catalogue, p. 37, and Engl. Stud. viii. 62.

source.heading: Ælf. Ep. lst
source.body: = L. Ælfc. P. (q.v.).

source.heading: Ælf. Test.
source.body: Ælfric on the Old Testament in Sweet's Anglo-Saxon Reader (1st ed.).

source.heading: Ælfc. Gen. Thw.
source.body: The preface to Genesis in Thwaites' edition of the Heptateuch. v. Gen.

source.heading: Ælfc. Gl.
source.body: Codex Junii 71, in the Bodleian Library. See Wanley's Catalogue, p. 96. Printed by Somner (Som.) at the end of his Dictionary, and again by Wright in A Volume of Vocabularies (Wrt. Voc.). In the early part of the Dictionary the page of the MS., and the page and number of the word in Somner and in Wright are given, but later the reference is to Wright only (Wrt. Voc. i.).

source.heading: Ælfc. Gl.; Zup.
source.body: Ælfric's Grammatik und Glossar, herausgegeben von Julius Zupitza, Berlin, 1880. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Ælfc. Gr.
source.body: Ælfric's Grammar, referred to at first in the edition by Somner, printed with his Dictionary (Som.), later in that of Zupitza (Zup. v. preceding explanation). Quoted by section of the Grammar, and by page and line of the editions.

source.heading: Ælfc. pref. Gen.
source.body: = Ælfc. Gen. Thw.

source.heading: Ælfc. T. or Ælfc. T. Lisle.
source.body: A Saxon treatise concerning the Old and New Testament. . . . Now first published in print with English of our times by William L'Isle, London, 1623. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Ælfc. T. Grn.
source.body: The same text, in vol. i. of Bibliothek der Angelsächsischen Prosa, herausgegeben von Chr. Grein. 1872. See also Ælf. Test.

source.heading: Æqu. Vern.
source.body: This contraction (used, but not explained, by Lye) seems to refer to the Anglo-Saxon abridgement of Bede's De Natura Rerum in MS. Cotton. Tiberius, B. V. (see Wanley's Catalogue, p. 216). It is printed in Popular Treatises on Science, edited for the Historical Society of Science by Wright, London, 1841 (Wrt. popl. science); and again in the 3rd vol. of Cockayne's Leechdoms (Lchdm. III). The later quotations are taken from the latter edition. v. Equin. vern.

source.heading: Al.
source.body: The Life of St. Alexius, edited by F, J. Furnivall, E.E.T.S., No. 69, 1878. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Alb. resp.
source.body: Albini responsa ad Sigewulfi interrogationes. For a text and MSS. see Anglia, vol. vii. pp. 1 sqq.

source.heading: Ald.
source.body: Sancti Aldhelmi Opera, edited by J, A. Giles, Oxford, 1844. Quoted by page.

source.heading: Alex.
source.body: The Alliterative Romance of Alexander, edited by J. Stevenson, Roxburghe Club, 1849. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Alex. (Skt).
source.body: The same, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., No. lxvii., 1866. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Alis.
source.body: King Alisaunder, in Weber's Metrical Romances, vol. i., Edinburgh, 1810. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Allit. Pms.
source.body: Early English Alliterative Poems, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., No. 1, 1864. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Am. and Amil.
source.body: Amis and Amiloun, in Weber's Metrical Romances, vol. ii.

source.heading: An. Lit.
source.body: Anecdota Literaria, edited by Thomas Wright, London, 1844. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: An. (or Anal.) Th. or Th. An. (Anal., Anlct.).
source.body: Analecta Anglo-Saxonica, by Benjamin Thorpe, London, 1846. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: And.
source.body: = St. And. (q.v.).

source.heading: Andr. Grm.
source.body: See Grm[m]. A. u. E.

source.heading: Andr. Kmbl.
source.body: The Poetry of the Codex Vercellensis, edited by J. M. Kemble for the Ælfric Society. Part 1. The Legend of St. Andrew, London, 1844.

source.heading: Andr. Recd.
source.body: The same poem edited for the Record Commission by Benjamin Thorpe, but not published. See Glos. Epnl. Recd.

source.heading: Andrews' Old English Manor.
source.body: The Old English Manor, a study in English Economic History, by Charles McLean Andrews, Baltimore, 1892.

source.heading: Anglia.
source.body: Anglia, Zeitschrift für Englische Philologie. Halle, 1878-

source.heading: Anlct.
source.body: v. An. Th.

source.heading: Ap. (Apol.) Th. or Th. Ap. (Apol.).
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon Version of the Story of Apollonius of Tyre, from a MS. in the Library of C. C. C., Cambridge (v. Wanley's Catalogue, p. 146), edited by Benjamin Thorpe, London, 1834. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: App. (Lib.) Scint.
source.body: v. Scint.

source.heading: Apstls. Crd.
source.body: An interlinear version of the Apostles' Creed on folio 199a of the MS. referred to as Ps. Lamb. (q.v.).

source.heading: Apstls. Kmbl.
source.body: The Fates of the Twelve Apostles in The Poetry of the Codex Vercellensis, Part II. v. Andr, Kmbl,

source.heading: Apstls. Recd.
source.body: The same poem edited for the Record Commission; v. Andr. Recd.

source.heading: Arth. and Merl.
source.body: Arthour and Merlin, a Metrical Romance edited by W. D. Turnbull, Abbotsford Club, 1838. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Ass. B.
source.body: Assumpcio Beate Marie, edited by J. R. Lumby, E.E.T.S., No. 14, 1866. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Ath. Crd. or Athan.
source.body: An interlinear version of the Athanasian Creed, folios 200a-202b of the MS, referred to as Ps. Lamb, (q, v.). Quoted by paragraph.

source.heading: Ayenb.
source.body: Dan Michel's Ayenbite of Inwyt, in the Kentish Dialect, 1340, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., No, 23, 1866.

source.heading: Bailey.
source.body: An Universal Etymological English Dictionary, by N. Bailey, 10th edition, London, 1742.

source.heading: Basil admn.; Norm.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon Remains of St. Basil's Admonitio ad filium spiritualem, edited by the Rev. Henry W. Norman, 2nd edition, London, 1849. Quoted by chapter, and by page and line.

source.heading: Bd. de nat. rm. (rerum).
source.body: See under Æqu. Vern.

source.heading: Bd.; M.
source.body: The Old English Version of Bede's Ecclesiastical History of the English People, edited by Thomas Miller, E.E.T.S., Nos. 95, 96, 1890-1891. Quoted by book and chapter, and by page and line.

source.heading: Bd. S.
source.body: Baedae Historia Ecclesiastica a gloriosissimo veterum Anglo-Saxonum rege Aluredo Saxonice reddita, cura et studio Johannis Smith, Cantabrigiae, 1722. Quoted as in previous work.

source.heading: Bd.; Whel. (Whelc.).
source.body: Bedae Venerabilis Historia Ecclesiastica Anglorum, Anglo-Saxonice ex versione Ælfredi Magni Gentis et Latine, cura Abrahami Wheloci, Cantabrigiae, 1644.

source.heading: Ben.
source.body: Vocabularium Anglo-Saxonicum, opera Th. Benson, Oxoniae, 1701.

source.heading: Beo. Kmbl.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon poems of Beowulf, the Traveller's Song and the Battle of Finnesburh, edited by John M. Kemble, 2nd edition, London, 1835.

source.heading: Beo. Th.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon Poem of Beowulf, edited by Benjamin Thorpe, Oxford, 1855.

source.heading: Beves.
source.body: Sir Beves of Hamtune, edited by E. Kölbing, E.E.T.S., Nos, xlvi., xlviii., 1885-1886. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Blickl. Gl. (Gloss.).
source.body: Glosses taken from a copy of the Roman Psalter in the library at Blickling Hall. Printed at the end of the Blickling Homilies. See next paragraph.

source.heading: Blickl. Homl. or Homl. Blick.
source.body: The Blickling Homilies, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., Nos. 58, 63, 1874-1876. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Boutr. (Btwk.) Scrd.
source.body: Screadunga. Anglo-Saxonica maximam partem inedita publicavit C. G. Bouterwek, Elberfeld, 1858. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Brand.
source.body: Popular Antiquities of Great Britain, edited, from the materials collected by John Brand, by W. C. Hazlitt. Three vols. London, 1870.

source.heading: Bridf[r].
source.body: Bridferth's Enchiridion contained in MS. No. 328 in the Ashmolean Library (see Wanley's Catalogue, p. 103). Quoted by folio. This MS. is printed in Anglia viii. 298-337, and later references are to this edition by page and line.

source.heading: Bt.; Fox.
source.body: King Alfred's Anglo-Saxon version of Boethius de Consolatione Philosophiae, edited by the Rev. S. Fox. Bohn's Antiquarian Library, London, 1864. Quoted by chapter and paragraph, and by page and line.

source.heading: Bt. Met. Fox and Bt. Tupr.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon metrical version of the metrical portions of Boethius, with a verse translation by M. Tupper. At the end of the previous work. Quoted by number of metre and line.

source.heading: Bt.; Rawl.
source.body: Boethii Consolationis Philosophiae libri v Anglo-Saxonice redditi ab Ælfredo; ad Apographum Junianum expressos edidit Christophorus Rawlinson, Oxoniae, 1698. Quoted by chapter and paragraph, and by page and line.

source.heading: Btwk.
source.body: Cædmon's Biblische Dichtungen, herausgegeben von K. W. Bouterwek. Erster Theil, Gütersloh, 1854. The references are to the Anglo-Saxon piece 'De officiis diurnalium et nocturnalium horarum,' preface, pp. cxciv-ccxxii. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Btwk. Scrd.
source.body: v. Boutr. Scrd.

source.heading: Byrht. Th.
source.body: The poem on the battle of Maldon in Thorpe's Analecta Anglo-Saxonica. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: C. L.
source.body: Castel off Love, edited by R. F. Weymouth, Philol. Soc., 1864. Quoted by line.

source.heading: C. M.
source.body: Cursor Mundi, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S. Quoted by line.

source.heading: C. R. Ben.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon version of the Benedictine Rule contained in a MS. in the library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge. See Wanley's Catalogue, p. 122. Quoted by chapter. In the latter part of the Dictionary references are given to the work noticed under R. Ben., in which this MS. is used,

source.heading: Cambr. MS. Ps.
source.body: = Ps. Spl. C. (q.v.).

source.heading: Canon. Hrs.
source.body: Appendix to Hickes' Letters to a Popish Priest. Quoted by page and line. The piece is printed in Select Monuments of the Doctrine and Worship of the Catholic Church in England before the Norman Conquest, by E. Thompson, London, 1875 (2nd edition).

source.heading: Cant. Ab. (Abac., Habac., Abac. Lamb.).
source.body: A gloss of Habakkuk, 3, 2-19, contained in the same MS. as Ps. Lamb. (q. v.) on folios 189-191. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Cant. Abac. Surt.
source.body: A gloss of the same material as the preceding, printed in An Anglo-Saxon and Early English Psalter, edited by J. Stevenson, Surtees Soc., No. 19. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Cant. (Cantic.) An.
source.body: A gloss of the song of Hannah (I. Sam. 2, l-10), contained in the same MS. as Ps. Lamb. (q. v.) on folios 185b - 186b. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Cant. Es.
source.body: A gloss of Isaiah 12, 1-6, contained in the same MS. as the preceding, on folio 184. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Cant. Ez. (Cant. Ezech. Lamb.).
source.body: A gloss of Isaiah 38, 10-20, contained in the same MS. as the preceding, on folios 184b - 185b. Quoted by verse (in some instances the folio of the MS. is also given).

source.heading: Cant. M. (Moys., Moys. Lamb.).
source.body: A gloss of Exodus 15, 1-19, contained in the same MS. as the preceding, on folios 186b - 189. Quoted as in the preceding.

source.heading: Cant. M. ad fil. (Moys. Isrl. Lamb.).
source.body: A gloss of Deuteronomy 32, 1-43, contained in the same MS. as the preceding, on folios 191-195. Quoted as in the preceding.

source.heading: Cant. Mar.
source.body: A gloss of Luke 1, 46-55, contained in the same MS. as the preceding, on folios 198-198b. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Cant. Moys. Ex. (Cantic. Moys.); Thw.: Cant. Moys. Thw.
source.body: A gloss of Exodus 15, 1-19, at the end of Thwaites' Heptateuch.

source.heading: Cant. Zach.
source.body: A gloss of Luke 1, 68-79, contained in the same MS. as Ps. Lamb. (q. v.) on folios 197-198. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Cart. Eadgif. R.
source.body: A charter of Queen Eadgifu, v. Chart. Th. 201.

source.heading: Cath. Ang. (Angl.).
source.body: Catholicon Anglicum, edited by S. J. Herrtage, E.E.T.S., No. 75, 1881. Quoted by page.

source.heading: Cd.; Th. (later Cd. Th.).
source.body: Cædmon's Metrical Paraphrase of parts of the Holy Scripture, in Anglo-Saxon, by Benjamin Thorpe, London, 1832. Quoted at first by folio, and by page and line, later by page and line.

source.heading: Chart. Erl.
source.body: A Handbook to the Land Charters, and other Saxonic Documents, by John Earle, M.A., Oxford, 1888. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Chart. (Ch.) Th.
source.body: Diplomatarium Anglicum Aevi Saxonici, by Benjamin Thorpe, London, 1865. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Chauc.
source.body: The abbreviations used in connexion with Chaucer are not given as not requiring explanation.

source.heading: Chr.; Erl.
source.body: Two of the Saxon Chronicles parallel with supplementary extracts from the others, edited by John Earle, M.A., Oxford, 1865. Quoted by year, and by page and line.

source.heading: Chr.; Gib.
source.body: Chronicon. Saxonicum, Latine et Anglo- Saxonice, cum notis Edmundi Gibson, Oxon., 1692.

source.heading: Chr.; Ing.
source.body: The Saxon Chronicle, with an English translation and notes, by the Rev. James Ingram, 1833.

source.heading: Chr.; Th.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, according to the several original authorities. Edited, with a translation, by Benjamin Thorpe, Master of the Rolls Series, 1861. Quoted by year, and by page, line, and column.

source.heading: Chron. Abing.
source.body: Chronicon Monasterii de Abingdon. Edited by Rev. J. Stevenson, Master of the Rolls Series, 1858.

source.heading: Chron. Vilodun.
source.body: Chronicon Vilodunense, sive de vita et miraculis sanctae Edithae, cur. W. H. Black. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Cl. and Vig. Dict.
source.body: An Icelandic-English Dictionary, based on the MS. collections of the late Richard Cleasby, enlarged and completed by Gudbrand Vigfusson, Oxford, 1874.

source.heading: Cod. Dip. B.
source.body: Cartularium Saxonicum: a collection of Charters relating to Anglo-Saxon History, by Walter de Gray Birch, London, 1883-1893. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Cod. Dip. (Dipl.) Kmbl.
source.body: Codex Diplomaticus Aevi Saxonici, opera Johannis M. Kemble. Publications of the English Historical Society, 1839-1848. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Cod. Exon.
source.body: v. Exon. Th.

source.heading: Coll. Monast. Th. or Wrt
source.body: Colloquium ad pueros linguae Latinae locutione exercendos ab Ælfrico compilatum. Printed in Thorpe's Analecta (v. An. Th.), or in Wright's Vocabularies (v. Wrt. Voc. i.). Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Confess. Pecc. (Peccat.).
source.body: A gloss of a 'Confessio pro peccatis ad Deum,' contained in the same MS. as Ps. Lamb, (q.v.) on folios 182b - 183 b.

source.heading: Corp. Gl. (ed.) Hessels.
source.body: An eighth-century Latin-Anglo-Saxon Glossary preserved in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, edited by J. H. Hessels, Cambridge, 1890. Quoted by page and number of word.

source.heading: Cot.
source.body: In the earlier part of the Dictionary several glossaries found among the Cotton MSS. are referred to by this abbreviation. These glossaries are printed in Wrt. Voc. i., ii., to which works later references are given; in a supplement to the Dictionary similar references will be found to replace the abbreviation in question.

source.heading: D. Arth.
source.body: Morte Arthure; or the Death of Arthur, edited by Edm. Brock, E.E.T.S., No. 8, 1871. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Dep. Rich.
source.body: Richard the Redeles, an Alliterative Poem on the Deposition of Richard II, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., No. 54, 1873. Quoted by passus and line.

source.heading: Destr. Tr.
source.body: The Gest Historiale of the Destruction of Troy, edited by G. A. Panton and D. Donaldson, E.E.T.S., Nos. 39, 56. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Deut.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of Deuteronomy in Thw. Hept. (q.v.) or in Bibliothek der Angelsächsischen Prosa, herausgegeben von Chr. Wilh. Mich. Grein, erster Band, 1872. Quoted by chapter and verse.

source.heading: Dial.
source.body: v. Gr. Dial.

source.heading: Dief.
source.body: Vergleichendes Wörterbuch der Gothischen Sprache, von Dr. Lorenz Diefenbach, 1851.

source.heading: Dietr.
source.body: Dietrich's Commentatio de Kynewulfi poetae aetate, Marburg, 1859 - 1860.

source.heading: Dóm. L.
source.body: Be Dómes Dæge, an Old English version of the Latin poem ascribed to Bede. Edited with other short poems from the MS. in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, by J. R. Lumby, E.E.T.S., No. 65, 1876. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: E. D. S. (Publ.).
source.body: The publications of the English Dialect Society.

source.heading: E. E. T. S.
source.body: The publications of the Early English Text Society.

source.heading: E. G.
source.body: English Gilds, edited by Miss L. Toulmin Smith, E.E.T.S., No. 40, 1870. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Earle A. S. Lit.
source.body: Anglo-Saxon Literature. By John Earle. London: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1884.

source.heading: Ecclus.
source.body: The book of Ecclesiasticus.

source.heading: Elen. Grm.
source.body: v. Grmm. A. u. E.

source.heading: Elen. Kmbl.
source.body: The Poetry of the Codex Vercellensis, edited for the Ælfric Society by J. M. Kemble. Part II. Elene and Minor Poems, London, 1856.

source.heading: Engl. Stud.
source.body: Englische Studien. Organ für englische Philologie. Herausgegeben von Dr. Eugen Kölbing.

source.heading: Ep. Gl. (Gloss. Ep.).
source.body: The Epinal Glossary, Latin and Old-English of the eighth century. Edited by Henry Sweet. Printed for the Philological and Early English Text Societies, 1883. Quoted by page, column and line.

source.heading: Equin. vern.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon summary of Bede's De Temporibus, referred to in Wanley's Catalogue under the heading De equinoctio vernali. It is printed in Lchdm. iii. pp. 232-280, and the quotations from the work are, except in the earlier part of the Dictionary, from this printed form. v. Æqu. Vern.

source.heading: Erf. Gl.
source.body: A Latin-Anglo-Saxon Glossary contained in a MS. preserved in the Amplomian library at Erfurt. Printed in the oldest English Texts, edited by Henry Sweet, E.E.T.S., No. 83, 1885.

source.heading: Ettm.
source.body: Lexicon Anglosaxonicum, edidit Ludovicus Ettmüllerus. Quedlinburgii. et Lipsiae, 1851.

source.heading: Ettm. Poet.
source.body: Anglosaxonum poetae atque scriptores prosaici. Edidit Ludovicus Ettmüllerus. Quedlinburgii et Lipsiae, 1850.

source.heading: Ex.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of Exodus, v. Deut.

source.heading: Exod. Thw.
source.body: v. preceding.

source.heading: Exon.; Th. (later Exon. Th.).
source.body: Codex Exoniensis. A Collection of Anglo-Saxon poetry, from a MS. in the library of the Dean and Chapter of Exeter, by Benjamin Thorpe, London, 1842; Quoted at first by folio, and by page and line, later by page and line.

source.heading: Fer.
source.body: Sir Ferumbras, edited by S. J. Herrtage, E.E.T.S., No. xxiv., 1879. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Fins. Th.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon poem of the Fight at Finnesburg, edited by Benjamin Thorpe. In the same volume with Beo. Th. (q.v.).

source.heading: Fl. a. Bl.
source.body: Floriz and Blauncheflur, edited by J. R. Lumby, E.E.T.S., No. 14, 1866. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Frag. Kmbl.
source.body: A Fragment, Moral and Religious, contained in the Poetry of the Codex Vercellensis, edited by J. M. Kemble (v. Elen. Kmbl.).

source.heading: Frag. Phlps.
source.body: Fragment of Ælfric's Grammar, Ælfric's Glossary, and a Poem on the Soul and the Body, in the orthography of the twelfth century, edited by Sir T. Phillipps, London, 1838.

source.heading: Frag. Recd.
source.body: The same poem as Frag. Kmbl., printed with Andr. Recd. (q. v.).

source.heading: Fulg.
source.body: S. Fulgentii Regulae Monachorum, an Anglo-Saxon gloss of the Latin work contained in MS. Cott. Tib. A. 3 (see Wanley's Catalogue, p. 91).

source.heading: Gam.
source.body: The Tale of Gamelin, edited by W. W. Skeat, Oxford, 1884. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Gaw.
source.body: Sir Gawayne and the Green Knight, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., No. 4, 1864. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Gen.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of Genesis. v. Deut.

source.heading: Gen. and Ex.
source.body: The Story of Genesis and Exodus, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., No. 7, 1865. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Gen. pref. Thw.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon preface to Genesis in Thw. Hept. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Germ.
source.body: Die Bouloneser Angelsächsischen Glossen zu Prudentius. Herausgegeben von Dr. Alfred Holder. In vol. xi. (new series) of Germania. Quoted by page and number preceding the gloss, v. Gl. Prud., Gl. Prud. H., Glos. Prudent. Recd.

source.heading: Gl. Amplon.
source.body: Glossae Amplonianae, ed. Oehler in Jahn's Jahrb. 13, 1847,

source.heading: Gl. E.
source.body: A Latin-Anglo-Saxon Glossary contained in MS. Cott. Cleopatra A III. (v. Wanley's Catalogue, p. 238). Printed in Wrt. Voc. ii. pp. 70 sqq., whence, except at the beginning, quotations are taken.

source.heading: Gl. M.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon Gloss of Aldhelm's De laude virginitatis, published in Mone's Quellen und Forschungen, Leipzig, 1830. Quoted by page. See Hpt. Gl., where the same gloss is referred to.

source.heading: Gl. Mett.
source.body: Glossae Mettenses in Mone Anzeiger, 1839.

source.heading: Gl. Prud.
source.body: (1). Glosses to Prudentius in Mone Anzeiger, 1839. Quoted by number of gloss. From the same M.S. as that given under Germ.

source.heading: Gl. Prud.
source.body: (2). The same abbreviation as the preceding has also sometimes been used for another work, Which elsewhere is referred to as Glos. Prud. (q.v.) or simply Prud. The quotations, however, in this case are by paragraph.

source.heading: Gl. Prud. H.
source.body: This is the gloss given under Germ. (q.v.). The quotations are by folio instead of by page.

source.heading: Gl. Wülck.
source.body: v. Wülck.

source.heading: Glos. Brux. Recd.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon Vocabulary taken from a MS. in the Royal Library at Brussels. It is printed in Wrt. Voc. i. pp. 62 sqq., and to this edition alone, except in the earlier part of the Dictionary, references are given.

source.heading: Glos. Epnl. Recd.
source.body: The Epinal Glossary printed (but not published) in Appendix B of An Account of the most important Public Records of Great Britain (Publications of the Record Commissioners), London, 1836.

source.heading: Glos. Prud. or Prud.
source.body: Englische Übersetzungen der lateinischen Erklärungen von Bildern zur Psychomachie des Prudentius entlehnt: (A) einer Hs. im Britischen Museum, Cotton. Cleop. C. viii, (B) einer Cambridger Hs., Corpus Christi College 23, published by J. Zupitza in Zeitschrift für deutsches Alterthum, vol. 8 (new series), 1876. Quoted by paragraph and MS.

source.heading: Glos. Prudent. Recd.
source.body: The glosses given under Germ., printed in the same work as the Glos. Epnl. Recd.

source.heading: Gloss. Ep.
source.body: v. Ep. Gl.

source.heading: Glostr. Frag.
source.body: Legends of Saint Swiðun and Sancta Maria Ægyptiaca, published by John Earle, M.A., London, 1861.

source.heading: Gospel of Nicodemus.

source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of Gregory's Dialogues. Quoted from Lye. v. Wanley's Catalogue, p. 71.

source.heading: Grff.

source.heading: Guthl. (Gu.); Gdwin.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of the Life of St. Guthlac, Hermit of Crowland, edited by C. W. Goodwin, London, 1848. Quoted by chapter (Guthl.) and by page and line (Gdwin.).

source.heading: H. (K.) de visione Isaiae.
source.body: The reference is to Wanley's Catalogue, p. 27, l. 9; the passage will be found Wulfst. 44, 23.

source.heading: H. S.

source.heading: H. Z. (Hpt., Hpt. Zeit[sch].).
source.body: Zeitschrift für deutsches Alterthum, herausgegeben von Moritz Haupt.

source.heading: Hall. (Halliw., Halwl.) Dict.
source.body: A Dictionary of Archaic and Provincial Words, by J. O. Halliwell. Seventh edition, London, 1872.

source.heading: Handl. Synne.
source.body: v. H. S.

source.heading: Harl. Gl. 978.
source.body: This glossary is printed at p. 139 of Wrt. Voc. i.

source.heading: Hél.

source.heading: Heli. Schmel.

source.heading: Hem. (Heming.).
source.body: Hemingi Chartularium Eccl. Wigor- niensis, edidit T. Hearne, Oxon., 1723. Tom. ii.

source.heading: Herb.; Lchdm. i.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon Herbarium printed in Lchdm. i. Quoted by section and paragraph (Herb.), and by page and line. See Lchdm.

source.heading: Hexam. (Hex.); Norm.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of the Hexameron of St. Basil, edited by H. W. Norman. 2nd edition, London, 1849. Quoted by chapter (Hexam.), and by page and line (Norm.).

source.heading: Hick. Thes.
source.body: Linguarum veterum septentrionalium thesaurus, auctore G. Hickesio, Oxpniae, 1705.

source.heading: Hick. Diss. Ep. (Hickes' Diss.),
source.body: G. Hickesii de antiquae litteraturae septentriorialis utilitate dissertatio epistolaris, Oxoniae, 1703. Contained in vol. i. of the preceding.

source.heading: Hom.
source.body: = O. E. Homl.

source.heading: Hom. de Comp. Cord.
source.body: Cited by Dr. Bosworth from Lye.

source.heading: Hom. 8 Cal. Jan.
source.body: This homily is printed in Homl. Th. i. 28. [v. ge-þryle, the reference to which = Homl. Th. i 34, 34.]

source.heading: Homl. As[s].
source.body: Angelsächsische Homilien und Heiligenleben, herausgegeben von Bruno Assman, Kassel, 1889. [Bibliothek der Angelsächsischen Prosa, begründet von C. W. M. Grein, 3. Band.] Quoted by page and line of section.

source.heading: Homl. Blick.
source.body: v. Blickl. Homl.

source.heading: Homl. in nat. Innoc.
source.body: This homily is printed in Homl. Th. i. 76. [v. &aelig-acute;rst, the reference to which = Homl. Th. i. 78, 18.]

source.heading: Homl. Pasc. Daye.
source.body: A Sermon of the Paschall Lambe to be spoken unto the people at Easter. Imprinted (with other works of Ælfric) at London by John Daye, 1567.

source.heading: Homl. Pasc. Lisl.
source.body: The same homily as the preceding, published in 1623 by Lisle. The homily is printed in Homl. Th. ii. 262.

source.heading: Homl. Skt.
source.body: Ælfric's Metrical Lives of Saints, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., Nos. 76, 82, 94, 1881-85-90. Quoted by volume, homily and line.

source.heading: Homl. Th.
source.body: The Homilies of Ælfric, edited by B. Thorpe for the Ælfric Society, London, 1844-1846. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Horn (K[ing] Horn).
source.body: King Horn, edited by J. R. Lumby, E.E.T.S., No. 14, 1866. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Hpt.
source.body: v. H. Z.

source.heading: Hpt. Gl.
source.body: Die Angelsächsischen Glossen in dem Brüsseler Codex von Aldhelms Schrift De Virginitate, published in vol. ix. of Haupt's Zeitschrift, by K. Bouterwek. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Hpt. Zeit[sch].
source.body: v. H. Z.

source.heading: Hymn. ad Mat.
source.body: Hymnus ad Matutinos Dies Dominicos, contained in fols. 195-196 of Ps. Lamb. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Hymn. in Dedic. Eccles. (Hymn.).
source.body: The piece referred to will be found printed in Homl. Th. ii. 576 sqq.

source.heading: Hymn. L.
source.body: = Hymn. ad Mat.

source.heading: Hymn. Lye
source.body: = Hymnarium in Cott. MS. Jul. A. 6.

source.heading: Hymn. Surt.
source.body: Anglo-Saxon Hymnarium, edited by Rev. J. Stevenson, Surtees Society, vol. xxiii., 1851. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Hymn. T. P.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon gloss of Dan. 3, 57-88, contained in the same MS. as Ps. Lamb, on folios 196-197. Quoted by verse.

source.heading: Icel.
source.body: Icelandic; the forms are taken from Cleasby and Vigfusson's Dictionary.

source.heading: Invent. Crs. Recd.
source.body: The poem in the Codex Vercellensis on the finding of the Cross (v. Elen. Kmbl.), edited for the Record Commission by Benjamin Thorpe, but not published. See Andr. Recd.

source.heading: Jamieson.
source.body: Jamieson's Dictionary of the Scottish Language, abridged by J. Johnstone. A new edition by J. Longmuir Edinburgh, 1877.

source.heading: Japx.
source.body: Gysbert Japicx, a Friesian poet, who wrote about 1650.

source.heading: Jellinghaus.
source.body: Die Westfälischen Ortsnamen nach ihren Grundwörtern, von H. Jeilinghaus. Kiel und Leipzig, 1896.

source.heading: Jn.
source.body: The Gospel of St. John. v. Mt.

source.heading: Job Thw.
source.body: A portion of Ælfric's homily on Job (v. Homl. Th. ii. 446) printed in Thw. Hept. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Jos.
source.body: (1). The Anglo-Saxon version of the book of Joshua. v. Deut.

source.heading: Jos.
source.body: (2). (Jos. of Arith.). Joseph of Arimathie, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., No. 44, 1871.

source.heading: Josc.
source.body: For the passage under sliten cited from Joscelin by Lye, see Lk. Spt. p. 2, 11. For Joscelin's Dictionary see Wanl. Cat. p. 101.

source.heading: Jud.
source.body: (1). The Anglo-Saxon Version of the book of Judges. v. Deut.

source.heading: Jud.
source.body: (2) (Jud. Thw.). Where the quotation is by page and line the reference is to the matter printed in Thw. Hept. at the end of the book of Judges.

source.heading: Jud.
source.body: (3); See under the contractions used in Grein's Dictionary.

source.heading: Jud. Civ. Lund.
source.body: Judicia Civitatis Lundoniae. L. Ath. v.; Th. i. 228.

source.heading: Judth.; Thw.
source.body: (later Judth. Thw.). The poem of Judith printed at the end of Thw. Hept. Quoted by section (Judth.), and by page and line (Thw.).

source.heading: Jul.
source.body: (Juliana). The Liflade of St. Juliana, edited by O. Cockayne and T. Brock, E.E.T.S., No. 51, 1872. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: K. Alis.
source.body: v. Alis.

source.heading: Kath.
source.body: The Life of Saint Katherine; in the earlier part of the Dictionary reference is to the edition of Rev. J. Morton, later to that of Dr. E. Einenkel, E.E.T.S., No. 80, 1884. Quoted by line. The correspondence of lines in the two editions is marked in the later.

source.heading: Kent. Gl.
source.body: Kentische Glossen des neunten Jahrhunderts, published in Zeitschrift für deutsches Alterthum, vol. ix., new series, by J. Zupitza. These glosses, from MS. Cott. Vesp. D 6, are on the book of Proverbs, and in the earlier part of the Dictionary the abbreviation used is Prov.; in this case the quotation is by chapter, in the other by the number of the gloss.

source.heading: Ker.
source.body: Kero, the name assumed to be that of the author of a glossary, and of a gloss of the Benedictine Rule, in the Alemannic dialect.

source.heading: Kil.
source.body: Etymologicum Teutonicae linguae, sive dictionarium Teutonico-Latinum, studio et opera Corn. Kiliani Dufflaei, Antverpiae, 1599.

source.heading: King Horn.
source.body: v. Horn.

source.heading: Kmbl. Cod. Dipl.
source.body: v. Cod. Dipl. Kmbl.

source.heading: Kmbl. Sal. and Sat.
source.body: v. Salm. Kmbl.

source.heading: L.; Th.
source.body: The following contractions refer to the matter contained in Ancient Laws and Institutes of England, edited by Benjamin Thorpe, and printed under the direction of the Commissioners on the Public Records of the Kingdom, 1840. Quoted by (section and) paragraph (L. &emdash;), and by volume, page and line (Th.) :&emdash;

source.body: Alfred and Guthrum's Peace.

source.heading: L. Ælfc. C.

source.body: = L. Edg., L. Edg. S., L. E. I. L. Ecg. P. addit.

source.heading: L. Edw. Conf. Schmid.
source.body: The Laws of King Edward the Confessor in Schmid's A. S. Gesetz. (q.v.).

source.heading: L. H. R.
source.body: = H. R.

source.heading: L. Lund.
source.body: = L. Ath. v.

source.heading: L. M. 1, 2, 3.
source.body: Three books on medicine, contained in Lchdm. ii. Quoted by book and section; in the latter part of the Dictionary the references are to Lchdm. only.

source.heading: L. Med. ex Quadr.
source.body: = Med. ex Quadr.

source.heading: L. N. F.
source.body: Altenglische Legenden, neue Folge, herausgegeben von C. Horstmann, Heilbronn, 1881. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: L. S.
source.body: Lives of Saints, edited by C, Hortsmann, E.E.T.S., No. 87, 1887. Quoted by page and line of poem.

source.heading: L. Th.
source.body: Thorpe's edition of the Laws given under L.; Th.

source.heading: Lambd.
source.body: Lambard's edition of the Laws printed in 1568.

source.heading: Laym.
source.body: La&yogh;amon's Brut, edited by F. Madden, Society of Antiquaries, London, 1847. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Lchdm.
source.body: Leechdoms, Wortcunning, and Starcraft of early England, edited by O. Cockayne, Master of the Rolls Series, 3 vols. London, 1864-1866. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Leo A. S. Names.
source.body: A treatise on the local nomenclature of the Anglo-Saxons, translated from the German of Prof. H. Leo, London, 1852.

source.heading: Leo A. Sax. Gl.
source.body: Angelsächsisches Glossar von H. Leo, Halle, 1877.

source.heading: Lev.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of the book of Leviticus. v. Deut.

source.heading: Lk.
source.body: The Gospel of St. Luke. v. Mt.

source.heading: LL. Th.
source.body: = L. Th.

source.heading: Lupi Serm.
source.body: v. Wulfst.

source.heading: Lye.
source.body: Dictionarium Saxonico- et Gothico-Latinum. Auctore Eduardo Lye. Edidit Owen Manning, London, 1772.

source.heading: M. H.
source.body: The MS. so quoted has now been printed, v. Homl. Skt.

source.heading: Man. ed. Furn. (F).
source.body: Robert Manning's History of England, edited by F. J. Furnivall, Rolls Series, London, 1887. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Mand.
source.body: The Voiage and Travaile of Sir John Maundeville, edited by J. O. Halliwell, London, 1883.

source.heading: Manip. Vocab.
source.body: Levins' Manipulus Vocabulorum, a riming Dictionary, 1570, edited by H. B. Wheatley, E.E.T.S., No. 27, 1867.

source.heading: Mann.
source.body: Manning's edition of Lye's A. S. Dict., particularly the Supplement.

source.heading: Mapes.
source.body: The Latin Poems commonly attributed to Walter Map, edited by T. Wright, Camderi Soc., No. xvi., 1841. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: March.
source.body: A comparative grammar of the Anglo-Saxon language, by F. A. March, New York, 1873.

source.heading: Marg.
source.body: Seinte Margarete, edited by O. Cockayne (in the same volume as the next). Quoted by line.

source.heading: Marh.
source.body: Seinte Marherete, þe meiden ant martyr, edited by O. Cockayne, E.E.T.S., No. 13, 1866. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Martyr. (Martyrol.).
source.body: Martyrologium in Bibl. C. C. C. Cant. D. 5. v. Wanl. Catal. p. 106. Alterum exemplar, mutilum licet, multa tamen continens quae in superiori desiderantur, occurrit in Bibl. Cott. Jul. A. 10, v. Wanl. Catal. p. 185. The MSS. thus referred to by Lye are used by Cockayne in Shrn. pp. 44-156, and from this edition most passages are taken in the Dictionary. The quotation by month and day of Martyr. makes reference to Shrn. easy.

source.heading: Med. ex Quadr.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon version of the Medicina de Quadrupedis of Sextus Placitus, printed in Lchdm. i. Quoted by section and paragraph.

source.heading: Med. Pec.
source.body: For the passage given under ágotenes with this abbreviation see L. Ecg. C. 2; Th. ii. 136, 20.

source.heading: Menol. Fox.
source.body: Menologium seu Calendarium Poeticum, ex Hickesiano Thesauro, edited by S. Fox, London, 1830. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Met[r]. Homl.
source.body: English Metrical Homilies from MSS. of the 14th century, edited by J. Small, Edinburgh, 1862. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Mid. York. Gl.
source.body: A glossary of words pertaining to the dialect of Mid-Yorkshire, by C. C. Robinson, E.D.S., 1876.

source.heading: Migne.
source.body: Lexicon Manuale ad Scriptores mediae et infimae. Latinitatis, par M. L'Abbe Migne, Paris, 1866.

source.heading: Min.
source.body: The Poems of Laurence Minot, edited by J. Hall, Oxford, 1887. Quoted by number of poem (or of page) and line.

source.heading: Mirc.
source.body: Instructions for Parish Priests by John Myrc, edited by E. Peacock, E.E.T.S., No. 31, 1868. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Misc.
source.body: An Old English Miscellany, edited by R. Morris. E.E.T.S., No. 49, 1872. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Mk.
source.body: The Gospel of St. Mark. v. Mt.

source.heading: Mobr.
source.body: Venerabilis Baedae Historia Ecclesiae Gentis Anglorum, cura G. H. Moberly, Oxon., 1869.

source.heading: Mod. Confit.
source.body: Confessio et oratio ad Deum, MS. Cott. Tib. A. 3, fol. 44, v. Wanl. Cat. p. 195. See an edition of this piece, Anglia xi. 112-115.

source.heading: Mod. Lang. Notes.
source.body: Modern Language Notes, Baltimore.

source.heading: Mone.
source.body: Mone's Quellen und Forschungen zur Geschichte der teutschen Literatur und Sprache, Leipzig, 1830.

source.heading: Mone A.
source.body: A copy of the same glossary as Glos. Brux. Recd. printed in Mone.

source.heading: Mone B.
source.body: A copy of the same glossary as Hpt. Gl. printed in Mone.

source.heading: Morris Spec. i.
source.body: Specimens of Early English, edited by R. Morris, Part I. Oxford, 1882. Quoted by page and line of section.

source.heading: Mort A.
source.body: Morte Arthure, edited by E. Brock, E.E.T.S., No. 8, 1865. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Morte Arthure (Halliwell).
source.body: From a MS. quoted in Halliwell's Dictionary.

source.heading: Mt.
source.body: The Gospel of St. Matthew. Several editions of various versions of the Gospels are referred to, for a detailed notice of which see Prof. Skeat's preface to his edition of St. Mark's Gospel in the series noted below under Kmbl.

source.heading: Bos.
source.body: The Gothic and Anglo-Saxon Gospels with the versions of Wycliffe and Tyndale, edited by J. Bosworth, London, 1865.

source.heading: Foxe.
source.body: The Gospels of the fower Euangelistes, translated in the olde Saxon tyme out of Latin into the Vulgare toung of the Saxons, London, printed by John Daye, 1571. This work was published by Fox, the Martyrologist.

source.heading: Hat.
source.body: The Hatton MS. in the Bodleian Library, at Oxford, marked 38. See Wanl. Cat. p. 76.

source.heading: Jun.
source.body: Quatuor D. N. Jesu Christi Euangeliorum versiones perantiquae duae, Gothica scil. et Anglo-Saxonica; illam ex Codice Argenteo depromsit Franciscus Junins, hanc curavit Thomas Mareschallus, Dordrechti, 1665.

source.heading: Kmbl.
source.body: The Gospel according to Saint Matthew in Anglo-Saxon and Northumbrian Versions. Cambridge, 1858. The work was begun by J. M. Kemble and completed by Mr. Hardwick. The other Gospels were edited by Prof. Skeat, who in 1887 edited this Gospel also.

source.heading: Lind.
source.body: MS. Cott. Nero D. 4. The Latin Text was written in the island of Lindisfarne. See Wanl. Cat. p. 250.

source.heading: Rl.
source.body: MS. Bibl. Reg. I. A. xiv. See Wanl. Cat. p. 181.

source.heading: Rush.
source.body: MS. Auct. D. ii. 19, in the Bodleian Library at Oxford. The MS. was at one time in the possession of John Rushworth, deputy-clerk to the House of Commons during the Long Parliament, and was by him presented to the Bodleian Library. See Wanl. Cat. p. 31.

source.heading: Skt.
source.body: v. Kmbl.

source.heading: Stv.
source.body: An edition of the Lindisfarne and Rushworth Gospels was published by the Surtees Society (Nos. 28, 39, 43, 48, 1854-1865), the first volume being edited by Rev. J. Stevenson, the last three by G. Waring.

source.heading: Th.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of the Holy Gospels, edited by B. Thorpe, London and Oxford, 1842.

source.heading: War.
source.body: v. Stv.

source.heading: N.
source.body: Dictionarium Saxonico-Anglicum Laurentii Noelli, in the Bodleian Library. See Wanl. Cat. p. 102.

source.heading: N. P.
source.body: Nugae Poeticae. Select pieces of Old English popular poetry, edited by J. O. Halliwell, London, 1844. Quoted by page.

source.heading: Nar.
source.body: Narratiunculae Anglice conscriptae, edited by O. Cockayne, London, 1861. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Nat. S. Greg. Els.
source.body: An English-Saxon Homily on the Birthday of St. Gregory, translated into Modern English by Elizabeth Elstob, London, 1709 (cf. Homl. Th. ii. 116). Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Nath. (Nathan).
source.body: Nathanis Judaei legatio ad Tiberium Caesarem. It is contained in a MS. preserved in the University Library at Cambridge, described in Wanl. Cat. p. 152, and has been edited in Publications of the Cambridge Antiquarian Society by C. W. Goodwin, Cambridge, 1851. v. St. And., under which abbreviation references by page and line are given except in the earlier part of the Dictionary.

source.heading: Nicod. (Nic.); Thw. (Nicod. Thw.).
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon version of the Gospel of Nicodemus, printed in Thw. Hept.

source.heading: Num.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of the book of Numbers. v. Deut.

source.heading: O. and N.
source.body: An Old English poem of the Owl and the Nightingale, edited by F. H. Stratmann, Krefeld, 1868. Quoted by line.

source.heading: O. E[ngl.] Homl.
source.body: Old English Homilies, edited by R. Morris, E.E.T.S., first series, Nos. 29, 32; second series, No. 53, 1867-1868, 1873. Quoted by series, page and line.

source.heading: O. E. Misc.
source.body: = Misc.

source.heading: O. Frs.
source.body: Old Frisian; the forms are taken from Altfriesisches Worterbuch von Karl von Richthofen, Gättingen, 1840.

source.heading: O. H. Ger.
source.body: Old High German, v. Grff.

source.heading: O. L. Ger.
source.body: Old Low German; the references are mostly to Kleinere altniederdeutsehe Denkmäler, herausgegeben von M. Heyne, Paderborn, 1877.

source.heading: O. Nrs.
source.body: v. Icel.

source.heading: O. Sax.
source.body: v. Hél.

source.heading: Obs. Lun.
source.body: De obseruatione lune, printed from MS. Cott. Tib. A. iii. fol. 30b in Lchdm. iii. 184.

source.heading: Octo Vit. cap[it].
source.body: A homily De octo vitiis et de xii. abusivis, in a MS. of the Bodleian, Cod. Jun. 24, p. 329 (Wanl. Cat. p. 42). It is printed in O. E. Homl. i, 296-304. Cf. also Homl, Skt. i. 16, 246-384.

source.heading: Octov.
source.body: Octovian Imperator in Weber's Metrical Romances, vol. iii., 1810. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Off. episc[op].
source.body: The reference seems to be to the matter printed in Thorpe's Laws from Cod. Juni 121, and referred to as L. I. P. (e. g. á-wildian will be found, Th. ii. 322, 15).

source.heading: Off. reg[um].
source.body: The same MS. as the preceding seems sometimes to be referred to, e.g. efen-wel occurs Th. ii. 324, 2: but bæc-slitol I have noted only Wulfst. 72, 16, where the MS. is Cod. Jun. 99 (Wanl. Cat. p. 27).

source.heading: Orm.
source.body: The Ormulum, edited by R. M. White, Oxford, 1852. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Ors.; Bos.
source.body: King Alfred's Anglo-Saxon version of the compendious history of the world by Orosius, edited by J. Bosworth, London, 1859. Quoted by book and chapter (Ors.), and by page and line (Bos.).

source.heading: Ors. Hav.
source.body: The edition of Orosius by Havercamp, Leyden, 1738.

source.heading: Ors.; Swt.
source.body: King Alfred's Orosius, edited by H. Sweet, E.E.T.S., No, 79, 1883. Quoted by book and chapter (Ors.), and by page and line (Swt.).

source.heading: Ottf.
source.body: Otfrid's Krist, edited by E. G. Graff, Königsberg, 1831.

source.heading: P. B.
source.body: Beiträge zur Geschichte der deutschen Sprache und Literatur, herausgegeben von H. Paul und W. Braune.

source.heading: P. L. S.
source.body: Early English Poems and Lives of Saints, edited by F. J. Furnivall, Philol. Soc., 1862. Quoted by number of piece and line (or stanza).

source.heading: P. R. L. P.
source.body: Political, Religious, and Love Poems, edited by F. J. Furnivall, E.E.T.S., No. 15, 1866. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: P. S.
source.body: The Political Songs of England, from the reign of John to that of Edward II, edited by T. Wright, Camden Soc., No. vi., 1839. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Palgrv. Eng. Com.
source.body: Palgrave's Rise and Progress of the English Commonwealth, London, 1834.

source.heading: Pall.
source.body: Palladius on Husbondrie, edited by B. Lodge and S. T. Herrtage, E.E.T.S., Nos. 52 and 72, 1872 and 1879. Quoted by page and line of book.

source.heading: Parten.
source.body: The Romans of Partenay, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., No. 22, 1866. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Past.; Hat.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon version of Gregory's Pastoral Care, contained in a MS. (Hatton 20) preserved in the Bodleian Library. Quoted by chapter and paragraph of an edition of the Cura Pastoralis by J. Stephen, London, 1629 (Past.), and by folio and line of MS. (Hat.).

source.heading: Past.; Swt.
source.body: The Anglo-Saxon version of Gregory's Pastoral Care from the Hatton MS. and the Cotton MSS., edited by H. Sweet, E.E.T.S., Nos. 45 and 50, 1871-1872. Quoted by chapter (Past.), and by page and line (Swt.).

source.heading: Peccat[orum] Medic[ina]
source.body: = L. Pen. (e. g. áspíwan may be found L. Pen. 5; Th. ii. 278, 22).

source.heading: Pegge's Kenticisms.
source.body: An Alphabet of Kenticisms by Samuel Pegge, 1735. E. D. S., 1876.

source.heading: Piers [P.],
source.body: The Vision of William concerning Piers the Plowman (Text B), E.E.T. S., No. 38, 1869. [Texts A and C are Nos. 28 and 54.] Quoted by passus and line.

source.heading: Piers P. Crede.
source.body: Pierce the Ploughman's Crede, edited by W. W. Skeat, E.E.T.S., No. 30, 1867. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Pl. Cr.
source.body: = Piers P. Crede.

source.heading: Pol. Songs Wrt.
source.body: = P. S.

source.heading: Pr. C.
source.body: The Pricke of Conscience, by R. Rolle de Hampole, edited by R. Morris, Philol. Soc., 1863. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Pref. [Ælfc.]. Thw.
source.body: Ælfric's preface to Genesis in Thw. Hept. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Pref. (Procœm.) R. Conc[ord].
source.body: Prohemium regularis concordie Anglicae nationis monachorum (MS. Cott. Tib. A. 3, v, Wanl. Cat., p. 193). This is edited in Anglia, vol. xiii. p. 365, and in the later part of the Dictionary this edition is referred to.

source.heading: Prehn's Rätsel des Exeterbuches.
source.body: Komposition und Quellen der Rätsel des Exeterbuches, von Dr. August Prehn, Paderborn, 1883.

source.heading: Proclam. H. III.
source.body: The only English Proclamation of Henry III, edited by Alex. J. Ellis, Philol. Soc., 1868.

source.heading: Prompt. [Parv.].
source.body: Promptorium Parvulorum, sive Clericorum, dictionarius Anglo-Latinus princeps, auctore fratre Galfrido, recensuit Albertus Way, Camden Soc., Nos. xxv., liv., lxxxix., 1843-1865. Quoted by page.

source.heading: Prov.
source.body: Glosses on the book of Proverbs, which are printed as noticed under Kent. Gl. Quoted by. chapter (and verse).

source.heading: Prov. Kmbl.
source.body: Anglo-Saxon Apothegms in Sälm. Kmbl. (q. v.) Part III. pp. 258-268. Quoted by number.

source.heading: Prud.
source.body: v. Gl. Prud. (2).

source.heading: Ps.
source.body: An Early English Psalter, edited by J. Stevenson, Surtees Soc., Nos. 16, 19, 1843-1847. Quoted by psalm and verse.

source.heading: Ps. Grn.
source.body: The edition of the metrical version of Psalms 51-150 in Grein's Bibliothek der Angelsächsischen Poesie. 2. Band. Göttingen, 1858.

source.heading: Ps. Lamb.
source.body: An interlinear version of the Psalms in a MS. preserved in the library of Lambeth Palace. It is thus described by Wanley: Psalterium D. Hieronymi Gallicum, Astericis et obolis, punctisque Musicis subjectis notatum, una cum interlineata Versione Saxonica, Catalogue, p. 268.

source.heading: Ps. Spl.
source.body: Psalterium Davidis Latino-Saxonicum vetus. A Johanne Spelmanno D. Hen. fil. editum. E vetustissimo exemplari MS. in Bibliotheca ipsius Henrici, et cum tribus aliis non multo minus vetustis collatum, Londini, 1640. The MS. used by Spelman subsequently was in the library at Stowe, and has been described by Dr. O'Conor in his account of that library. Afterwards it passed into the possession of Lord Ashburnham. Of the three collated MSS., which Spelman refers to under the letters C, T, M, the first is in the University Library at Cambridge, see Wanl. Cat. p. 152; the second is in the library of Trin. Coll. Camb., and has been edited by F. Harsley, E.E.T.S., No. 92, 1889 (Eadwine's Canterbury Psalter); the third is Arundel MS. No. 60 in the British Museum. The printed edition, as regards C and T, was collated with those MSS. for Dr. Bosworth by Dr. Aldis Wright, and many corrections were made.

source.heading: Ps. Stev. or Surt.
source.body: An Anglo-Saxon Psalter (printed from MS. Cott. Vesp. A. 1), edited by J. Stevenson, Surtees Soc., Nos. 16, 19, 1843-1847.

source.heading: Ps. Th.
source.body: Libri Psalmorum versio antiqua Latina; cum paraphrasi Anglo-Saxonica, partim soluta oratione, partim metrice composita. E Cod. MS. in Bibl. Regia Parisiensi adservato descripsit et edidit B. Thorpe, Oxonii, 1835.

source.heading: Ps. Trin. Camb.
source.body: = Ps. Spl. T.

source.heading: Ps. Vos[sii].
source.body: An interlinear version of the Psalms in a MS. given by Isaac Vossius to Francis Junius (MS. Bodl. Junius 27). See Wanl. Cat. p. 76.

source.heading: R., Lye.
source.body: Ælfric's Vocabulary, transcribed by or for Junius from a MS. in the possession of Reubens the painter, v. Wanl. Cat. p. 96. It was printed by Somner at the end of his Dictionary, and will be found in Wrt. Voc. i. 15.

source.heading: R. Ben.
source.body: Die Angelsächsische Prosabearbeitung der Benedictinerregel, herausgegeben von A. Schröer, Kassel, 1885. Quoted (at first by chapter, later) by page and line.

source.heading: R. Ben. Interl.
source.body: The Rule of S. Benet. Latin and Anglo-Saxon interlinear version. Edited by H. Logeman, E.E.T.S., No. 90, 1888. Quoted (at first by chapter, later) by page and line.

source.heading: R. Brun[ne].
source.body: Peter Langtoft's Chronicle (as illustrated and improved by Robert of Brunne), published by Thomas Hearne, Oxford, 1725. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: R[eg.] Conc[ord].
source.body: v. Pref. R. Conc.

source.heading: R. Glouc.
source.body: Robert of Gloucester's Chronicle, published by Thomas Hearne, Oxford, 1724. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: R. R.
source.body: The Romaunt of the Rose, formerly attributed to Chaucer. Quoted by line.

source.heading: R. S.
source.body: Religious Songs, edited by Thomas Wright, Percy Soc., vol. xi., 1843. Quoted by number of piece and line.

source.heading: Rask Hald.
source.body: Björn Halldórsson's Icelandic-Latin Dictionary, edited by Rask, 1814.

source.heading: Recd.; Wrt. Voc.
source.body: v. Glos. Brux. Recd.

source.heading: Rel[iq.] Ant[iq.].
source.body: Reliquiae Antiquae. Scraps from Ancient Manuscripts, edited by T. Wright and J. O. Halliwell. 2 vols., London, 1845. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Rich.
source.body: Richard Coer de Lion, in Weber's Metrical Romances, vol. ii. 3-278. Quoted by line.

source.heading: Rol. H.
source.body: Richard Rolle of Hampole and his followers, edited by C. Horstmann. 2 vols., London, 1895. Quoted by volume, page and line.

source.heading: Rood Kmbl.
source.body: The Holy Rood, a poem in the Vercelli MS., published with Elen. Kmbl. (q. v.).

source.heading: Rood Recd.
source.body: The same poem as the preceding, printed as Andr. Recd. (q.v.).

source.heading: Rtl.
source.body: Rituale Ecclesiae Dunelmensis (Latin and interlinear Anglo-Saxon versions), Surtees Soc., No. 10, 1839. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Runic Inscrip. Kmbl.
source.body: On Anglo-Saxon Runes. By J. M. Kemble. Archaeologia, published by the Society of Antiquaries, vol. xxviii., London, 1846. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Runic pm. Kmbl.
source.body: A poem printed in the above paper. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: S. de Fide Cathol.
source.body: This homily is printed Homl. Th. i. 274.

source.heading: Salm. Kmbl.
source.body: Anglo-Saxon Dialogues of Salomon and Saturn, by J. M. Kemble. Printed for the Ælfric Society, London, 1845-1848. The poetical part is quoted by line, the prose by page and line.

source.heading: Sax. Engl.
source.body: The Saxons in England. A History of the English Commonwealth till the period of the Norman Conquest, by J. M. Kemble. 2 vols., London, 1876.

source.heading: Schmid [A. S. Gesetz].
source.body: Die Gesetze der Angelsachsen. Herausgegeben von Dr. R. Schmid, Leipzig, 1858.

source.heading: Scint.
source.body: Defensoris Liber Scintillarum, with an interlinear Anglo-Saxon version, edited by E. W. Rhodes, E.E.T.S., No. 93, 1889. Quoted (at first by chapter, later) by page and line of the interlinear version. App. [Lib.] Scint. refers to the matter in pp. 223 - 236 of this edition.

source.heading: Scóp. Th.
source.body: The Scóp or Gleeman's Tale printed in Beo. Th.

source.heading: Scot.
source.body: Scottish. v. Jamieson.

source.heading: Seebohm Vill. Comm.
source.body: The English Village Community examined in its relations to the Manorial and Tribal Systems, by F. Seebohm, London, 1890.

source.heading: Serm. Creat.
source.body: = Homl. Th. i. 8-28. (v. ge-dæman, where read ge-cl&aelig-acute;man.)

source.heading: Shor[eham].
source.body: The Religious Poems of William de Shoreham, edited by T. Wright, Percy Soc. vol. xxviii., 1849. Quoted by page.

source.heading: Shrn.
source.body: The Shrine. A Collection of occasional papers on dry subjects, by O. Cockayne, London, 1864-1870. Quoted by page and line.

source.heading: Skt. Dict.
source.body: An Etymological Dictionary of the English Language, by W. W. Skeat, Oxford, 1879-1882.

source.heading: Solil.
source.body: Soliloquia Augustini Selecta et Saxonice reddita ab Ælfredo Rege, MS. Cott. Vitell. A. 15, fol. I. (Printed in Shrn. pp. 163-204.) v. Wanl. Cat. p. 218.

source.heading: Som.
source.body: Dictionarium Saxonico-Latino-Anglicum, by E. Somner, Oxon., 1659.

source.heading: Somn.
source.body: De somniorum diuersitate (MS. Cott. Tib. A. iii. fol. 25 b) and De somniorum eventu (v. Wanl. Cat. p. 40). The two pieces are printed Lchdm, iii. pp. 198- 214, 168-176. Quoted by number of paragraph in the two combined. (In the later part of the Dictionary the references are to Lchdm. iii.)

source.heading: Soul Kmbl.
source.body: The departed soul's address to the body, a poem in the Vercelli MS. published with Elen. Kmbl. (q. v.).

source.heading: Soul Recd.

source.heading: Spec.

source.heading: St. And.

source.heading: Swt. A. S. Prim.

source.heading: Swt. [A. S.] Rdr.

source.heading: Techm.

source.heading: Te Dm. Lamb. (Te Deum; Lamb.).

source.heading: Te Dm. Lye.
source.body: v. Wanl. Cat. p. 222.

source.heading: Te Dm. Thomson.

source.heading: Thw. Hept.

source.heading: Txts.

source.heading: Tynd.

source.heading: V. Ps.

source.heading: Vit. Swith.

source.heading: W. Cat.

source.heading: W. F. (Wells Frag.).

source.heading: Wick.

source.heading: Will.

source.heading: Wrt. Biog. Brit. A. Sax.

source.heading: Wülck. [Gl.].

source.heading: Wulfst.

source.heading: Zacher.

source.heading: Ælfc. Gl; Som; Wrt. Voc.
